author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Ohio Woman Convicted of Murder in 1993 Death of Newborn
description: Genealogical research helped lead police to the baby’s identity nearly three decades later.
content: An Ohio woman was convicted on Monday of murder in the 1993 death of her newborn baby, whom the authorities said she put in a garbage bag and dumped in the state’s northern woods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Terry Wallis, 57, Dies; Awoke 19 Years After a Traumatic Brain Injury
description: Long after a car accident left him in a minimally conscious state in 1984, he woke up one day and said, “Mom.” Then he kept talking.
content: Terry Wallis, who spontaneously regained his ability to speak after a traumatic brain injury left him virtually unresponsive for 19 years, and who then became a subject of a major study that showed how a damaged brain could heal itself, died on March 29 in a rehabilitation facility in Searcy, Ark. He was 57.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: A Plan That Worked Perfectly, Until the Moment It Didn’t
description: Diego Simeone’s Atlético Madrid hunkered down and defended in its Champions League quarterfinal at Manchester City. But a single goal might be enough to send it packing.
content: MANCHESTER, England — After a while, feeling bored, cold and wet, Éderson decided to go for a walk. The Manchester City goalkeeper had spent 20 minutes dutifully guarding his penalty area. He had checked all four corners for danger. He found nothing. He had stared, squinting, into the distance, scanning for some threat on the horizon. Nothing there, either.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Warner
title: Is It Possible to Body-Block Our Loved Ones From Pain? Alas, No.
description: In her essay collection, “Bomb Shelter,” Mary Laura Philpott explores the pleasures, pitfalls and challenges of loving people who will leave.
content: BOMB SHELTERLove, Time and Other ExplosivesBy Mary Laura Philpott
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Anti-Abortion Activists Say They Were Allowed to Take 115 Fetuses
description: A medical waste disposal company denied their account. Most of the fetuses were buried in secret, the activists said, but they kept five that were later seized by the police in Washington, D.C.
content: Anti-abortion activists claimed on Tuesday that five fetuses that were removed from an apartment in Washington last week had been in a box containing a total of 115 that the driver of a medical waste truck voluntarily allowed them to take from his dolly outside an abortion clinic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Anderson
title: Learning the Right Way to Struggle
description: Several common educational strategies lean into the idea that, in the classroom, challenge is something to embrace.
content: When Hunter, 6, started first grade last autumn, he struggled to match letter sounds with the shape of letters on paper. He found writing letters hard and writing words even harder. “It felt bad,” he said recently.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The 2022 Grammys: Let’s Discuss
description: What are the awards at this point, and who benefits from them?
content: What exactly are the Grammys, at this point? A ceremony that honors the best in popular music? Sometimes, but not often. A concert that explores the connections between generations of styles and songs? On a good day, maybe. A party thrown by the stars and behind-the-scenes movers of yesteryear that young stars aren’t quite sure if they want to be invited to, or embraced by? Yes, that’s it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Biden Is Still Right. Putin Has to Go.
description: Russian atrocities in Ukraine require the West to take a harder stance.
content: Horrific scenes of mass murder on the outskirts of Kyiv should appall everybody and surprise nobody.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane O'Neill
title: An E-Commerce Site for Ukrainian Fashion
description: Angel for Fashion hopes to bring Ukrainian designs to customers all over the world — except Russia.
content: Angel for Fashion is a new e-commerce platform that sells the wares of 30 Ukrainian designers. The styles it offers are eclectic: There are breezy dresses inspired by traditional Ukrainian designs from the Foberini label; cheekily glamorous looks from Frolov; and macabre leather offerings, like Kofta bags and Bob Basset masks and harnesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: How Do You Supplant a ‘Walking Statue’? Cockiness Helps.
description: With no shortage of confidence, Walker Buehler is taking the reins from Clayton Kershaw as the Dodgers’ ace and opening day starter. Kershaw couldn’t be happier.
content: GLENDALE, Ariz. — The October air sizzled with excitement and suffocated with 103-degree game-time heat when Clayton Kershaw wound up and fired a heater of his own, a first-pitch fastball to Houston’s George Springer, to start Game 1 of the now intensely controversial 2017 World Series.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: What Ever Happened to the Great Resignation?
description: The past few months of data have pretty much destroyed this employment narrative.
content: All of the evidence suggests that right now, it’s unusually easy for U.S. workers to find jobs and unusually hard for employers to find workers. The odd thing is that we have a very tight labor market, even though the number of employees is still about a million and a half below prepandemic levels and even further below the prepandemic trend:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aina J. Khan and Andrés R. Martínez
title: The U.N. Security Council meets as Ukraine accuses Russia of atrocities.
description: Mr. Zelensky was expected to make the case that Russian forces have committed war crimes, as evidence emerges of civilian killings in the suburbs of Kyiv.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine is set to give one of his most high-profile speeches since the war began when he addresses the United Nations Security Council by video-link on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Louis Head Has Options (Just Not as Many)
description: Head was optioned to the minors 12 times by Tampa Bay in 2021, setting a record and inspiring a new rule. Now in Miami, he just might stick around.
content: JUPITER, Fla. — Baseball is a game of failure, they say, but it is all relative for Louis Head. A little more than a year ago, before he became The Man Of Many Options with a saga that inspired a rule change in Major League Baseball, Head was selling solar panels, door to door, in Arizona.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Waldstein
title: M.L.B. Approves Technology to Limit Sign Stealing
description: PitchCom devices will let catchers communicate secretly with pitchers and up to three fielders during games.
content: Old-fashioned finger signals and sign stealing may soon become obsolete in Major League Baseball. Teams will begin using electronic devices that transmit signals from catchers to pitchers starting this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Amazon Tried One of the Oldest Tricks in the Book, and It Backfired
description: The successful organization of a warehouse in Staten Island offers a real glimmer of hope for the American working class.
content: Faced with an unexpectedly strong organizing campaign by workers at one of its Staten Island warehouses, Amazon initially turned to one of the oldest tricks in the anti-union playbook: a little bit of racism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: A Battle Over Banning Gas and Oil Hookups in New Buildings
description: As the state struggles to enact a budget, the question of how to cut emissions from homes, offices, factories and shops rears its head.
content: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. Today we’ll explore a brewing battle over Gov. Kathy Hochul’s proposal to ban gas and oil hookups in new buildings. And we’ll find out why New York City’s switch to electric vehicles from gas-burning ones is off to a sluggish start.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: ‘Russia Is Half of Our Business.’ Or It Was.
description: European companies that relied on Russian customers are suffering collateral damage from the invasion of Ukraine and Western sanctions.
content: PARIS — The shoes, 600 pairs in all, lay untouched inside an Italian warehouse: magenta sandals, décolleté heels and gold ballerina flats, destined for Russian boutiques but stuck in a limbo of sanctions and economic upheaval from Russia’s war in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Wetmore
title: How Far Will Parents Go to Protect Their Sons?
description: In “The Lifeguards,” Amanda Eyre Ward imagines what happens when a group of teenagers discovers a dead body.
content: THE LIFEGUARDSBy Amanda Eyre Ward
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: We have the tools to slow warming
description: We actually have a better shot than we did a few years ago, according to a new United Nations report. But powerful interests stand in the way.
content: Maybe because I’m the child of immigrants. Or maybe because I’m a Virgo. I cringe at questions about climate hope. I also cringe at the hype that the planet is about to become unlivable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: The U.S. Economy Is Booming. So Why Are Economists Worrying About a Recession?
description: There is little sign that a recession is imminent. But sky-high demand and supply shortages are testing the economy’s limits.
content: Employers are adding hundreds of thousands of jobs a month, and would hire even more people if they could find them. Consumers are spending, businesses are investing, and wages are rising at their fastest pace in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Menker and Rajiv Shah
title: Putin’s War Has Started a Global Food Crisis
description: These are the countries that will be most affected by rising food prices.
content: The humanitarian disaster produced by Russia’s needless invasion of Ukraine shocks the conscience: 10 million Ukrainians displaced and innumerable Ukrainians killed. But because Ukraine and Russia are both major food exporters, the human toll will grow much larger, far from Ukraine’s borders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Alan J. Hruska, a Founder of Soho Press, Dies at 88
description: A litigator for 44 years, he was also a novelist; a writer, director and producer of plays and films; and helped establish the independent publishing house Soho Press.
content: Alan J. Hruska, a corporate litigator who had a second, wide-ranging career as a founder of the independent publishing house Soho Press, which invests in serious fiction by unsung authors; as a novelist; and as a writer, director and producer of plays and films, died on March 29 at his home in Manhattan. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Russians’ yellow-and-blue flight suits weren’t a political statement, a NASA astronaut says.
description: The Russians were “kind of blindsided,” that people thought they were making a political statement, Mark Vande Hei said. But the suits matched the colors of the university they all attended.
content: Three Russian astronauts were not making a political statement when they boarded the International Space Station in mid-March wearing yellow flight suits with blue highlights, the colors of the Ukrainian flag, according to a NASA astronaut who was on the station at the time to greet them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lena Wilson
title: ‘Meat the Future’ Review: The Growth of a ‘Clean Meat’ Start-Up
description: In her new film, the documentarian Liz Marshall depicts the rise of Upside Foods, a company that produces meat from animal cells.
content: With drama series about defective start-ups — like “The Dropout” and “WeCrashed” — in the spotlight, it’s weird to see a Bay Area-based biotech operation take off without turmoil. Yet that is the ultimate goal of Upside Foods, a new company headed by a cardiologist, Uma Valeti. By taking animals out of the process of meat production, the company hopes to minimize all kinds of strife to humans and livestock alike. In her new documentary, “Meat the Future,” the director Liz Marshall detachedly depicts Upside’s rise, starting in 2016. Opening narration by Jane Goodall describes this as “the next agricultural revolution.” But if you’re not well-versed in bioengineering or food regulation, it’s a bit of a slog.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: The C.D.C. will undergo a comprehensive re-evaluation, the agency’s director said.
description: Dr. Rochelle Walensky said that the appraisal would be the first step in modernizing the agency, which has received a barrage of criticism over its handling of the pandemic.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will undergo a monthlong comprehensive review and evaluation, a first step in modernizing its systems and processes and transforming it for the future, Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the agency’s director, announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall and Ivor Prickett
title: At Least 200 Feared Dead in Apartments Hit by Russia, Officials Say
description: After Russian forces withdrew from Borodyanka, a commuter town near Ukraine’s capital, families are searching the rubble for bodies.
content: BORODYANKA, Ukraine — Andreiy Ziuzko stood near the flattened apartment complex in Borodyanka that was once his home, his belongings in plastic bags on the sidewalk beside a few blackened cooking pots on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noor Qasim
title: How Should a Person Write
description: Some advice — helpful and otherwise — on the literary life, from living authors and Aristotle.
content: Writing a novel is daunting. Where to begin? And then how possibly to finish? With REFUSE TO BE DONE: How to Write and Rewrite a Novel in Three Drafts (156 pp., Soho Press, paper, $15.95), the author and professor Matt Bell presents a generously packed guide to this undertaking that effectively balances literary thinking with actionable advice, drawn from his own experiences and those of luminaries from Francine Prose to Samuel Delany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: June Brown, a Mainstay of Britain’s ‘EastEnders,’ Dies at 95
description: As the memorable Dot Cotton, she appeared in thousands of episodes of the hugely popular soap opera over 35 years.
content: June Brown, who appeared in thousands of episodes of the British soap opera “EastEnders” across 35 years, portraying Dot Cotton, one of the more memorable residents of the fictional Albert Square, died on Sunday at her home in Surrey, near London. She was 95.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Remy Martin Gets Finish Kansas Wanted After Rocky Season
description: Martin, a transfer from Arizona State, spent a significant part of the season with a knee injury. But he excelled come tournament time.
content: NEW ORLEANS — After the final buzzer, as he made his way across the court, the Kansas transfer guard Remy Martin stared triumphantly at the Jayhawks fans who were pressing against the Superdome’s railings to get as close as they could to him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Zelensky Addressed the U.N.
description: Plus a change in Shanghai’s controversial family Covid policy and the tense build-up to the French presidential election.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivered a fiery speech to the U.N. Security Council on Tuesday, a day after visiting Bucha, where images have surfaced of civilian bodies in the wake of Russia’s retreat.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Important Markings on Treasure Maps
description: Bruce Haight thinks he can do better than we can.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — The American Crossword Puzzle Tournament ran April 1 to 3, and I hope that those who attended had a fabulous time. Congratulations to everyone who competed. You can read more about the tournament in Alexis Benveniste’s tour of the A.C.P.T.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: Recalling One Activist Group’s Outraged Art at the Height of the AIDS Crisis
description: “It Was Vulgar & It Was Beautiful,” by Jack Lowery, recounts the daring efforts of Gran Fury to bring attention and resources to the cause.
content: The revolution would not be televised, but slathered with wheat paste.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Weapons and Sanctions
description: How can the world respond to Russian atrocities?
content: Civilians lay dead in the middle of the street. Others lay by the side of the road, next to or underneath their bicycles. Often, the victims had been shot in the head. Some of them had their hands tied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jen Doll
title: In ‘Atomic Anna,’ the Nuclear Disaster in Chernobyl Launches a Time-Traveling Adventure
description: Rachel Barenbaum’s latest novel is about Chernobyl, yes, but also about comic books, the power of math, finding one’s truth, and love, both biological and found.
content: ATOMIC ANNABy Rachel Barenbaum
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Eric Greitens Tests the Limits of the Trump Scandal-Survival Playbook
description: A leading Republican candidate for Senate in Missouri, Greitens faces new allegations from his ex-wife that join a long list of controversies. But for now, he’s staying in the race.
content: Lurid allegations of blackmail, sexual misconduct and child abuse would doom most politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: Hotel Life Without the Hotel
description: The designer Olympia Le-Tan has created a home goods line with the kind of stuff you’d steal (or want to steal) from a hotel.
content: During the early days of the pandemic, the designer Olympia Le-Tan missed traveling. Or rather, she missed hotels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paige McClanahan
title: In Europe, It’s Planes vs. Trains. For Many Travelers, Rail Is the Way to Go.
description: Amid concerns about climate change, Europe is investing heavily in trains. The idea is to make rail more appealing, especially as an alternative to short-haul flights.
content: Train travel in Europe is on the upswing, thanks to growing interest from travelers, a renaissance in sleeper trains, and new investments in high-speed rail lines across the continent. But to see major growth in passenger traffic — which is one of the goals of the European Green Deal — the continent’s railways will have to overcome a number of challenges, including booking difficulties and competition with short-haul flights, which remain the cheaper option on many multicountry routes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: E.P.A. to Propose Restrictions on Asbestos
description: The agency aims to ban the manufacturing and import of a type of asbestos that is used in brake pads, gaskets and other automotive products and is linked to cancer.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration said it intends to ban one form of asbestos, the first time the federal government has moved to significantly restrict the toxic industrial material since 1989.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kari Molvar
title: Fake Eyelashes That No Longer Look Quite So Fake
description: The latest generation of strips is easier on the eyes, and designed for an effect that’s subtle and startlingly realistic.
content: In 1999, Christie’s auctioned off a makeup case that had belonged to Marilyn Monroe for $266,500. Among its contents were lipsticks, nail polishes, perfumed lotions and a set of fluttery false eyelashes. Screen stars like Monroe and her midcentury contemporaries Lauren Bacall, Rita Hayworth and Sophia Loren often wore thick strips of inky dark lashes that framed their eyes on-screen and on the red carpet. They hardly looked real, but that wasn’t the point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Kiesling
title: Rags-to-Riches Stories Are Actually Kind of Disturbing
description: From Horatio Alger and E.L. James to T. Boone Pickens and Charles Koch, books by and about the ultrawealthy reveal some of our darkest American fantasies.
content: Americans retain their faith in the American dream even as our prospects of upward mobility dim. The lives of the billionaires whose ranks continue to swell give us cause to hope, or envy. We avidly follow the doings of the ultrarich, both the real (Kim Kardashian, Elon Musk) and the unreal (Bobby Axelrod, Logan Roy). This isn’t new: Americans have always loved fiction that reaffirms our fantasies about wealth and social mobility. Perhaps no cultural figure helped to keep the American dream on life support longer than Horatio Alger, the 19th-century novelist who wrote adventure stories for boys.
source.name: The New York Times

content: The word decrepit has appeared in 83 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 10 in “A Street Basketball Mecca Gets a Face-Lift” by Jonathan Abrams:

author: By Billy Witz
title: Kansas, With the Magic of a Record Comeback, Snatches Title Over North Carolina
description: The Jayhawks rallied from a 16-point deficit to down the Tar Heels in a thrilling — and intensely physical — N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament championship game.
content: NEW ORLEANS — As Kansas players glumly trudged off the Superdome floor at halftime on Monday night, down by 15 points, mired in foul trouble and dazed by a powder blue North Carolina hurricane, David McCormack was all smiles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Can I Utter a Racial Slur in My Classroom?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether a word should ever be off-limits.
content: I teach business law at a private university. One undergraduate course I teach is employment law, which covers discrimination under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. I believe it is important to explain the groundbreaking significance of this legislation to my students, so I delve into the de facto apartheid in the South, with its Jim Crow laws, the widespread discrimination against all types of minority groups and the resistance by many legislators, especially in the South, to the passage of this law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Up-Close Ukraine Atrocity Photographs Touch a Global Nerve
description: The apparent execution of Ukrainian civilians by retreating Russian forces, their bodies strewn in streets and yards, has focused attention on what constitutes crimes in war.
content: Perhaps it was the way the lifeless bodies, bloodied by bullets, and some with hands bound, had been left strewn about or shoveled into makeshift mass graves. Or the reality of seeing them up close in widely circulated photographs and videos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farah Fleurima
title: One Last Takeaway From ‘The Slap’: Leave Black Women’s Hair Alone
description: Lost in the Oscars fray is the hurt inflicted when a group is denigrated for a laugh. Chris Rock, who has examined this issue in a documentary, should have known better.
content: While the Slap Heard Round the World has been vigorously debated and dissected since Will Smith confronted Chris Rock at the Oscars, there was more to the incident than its abrupt physicality.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Parker-Pope
title: Do Home Covid Tests Expire?
description: A quirk in the regulatory process for home tests can mean the real expiration date doesn’t always match what’s on the box.
content: Q: Do home Covid tests really expire? I ordered what I was allowed. Now I see they have expiration dates. Some have already expired. What to do? Keep and use, or throw them out?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung
title: With U.S. Protection, a Tiny Toad Could Upend a Geothermal Project
description: The only place in the world where the species is found is on 760 acres of wetlands about 100 miles east of Reno, Nev., near a renewable energy project.
content: A tiny, black-freckled toad with an affinity for hot spring waters is imperiled by the development of a geothermal project in the Nevada desert, a federal agency said on Monday, announcing an emergency measure to list the Dixie Valley toad as an endangered species.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Forecasters Face Loss of Data as Weather Balloon Flights Are Cut
description: Disruptions to supplies of hydrogen and helium have led the National Weather Service to cancel routine launches at some sites.
content: The National Weather Service has cut back on weather balloon launches at some of its sites because of shortages of hydrogen and helium used to lift them, potentially affecting forecasts and weather and climate research.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Breaking Up With Russia
description: Companies are feeling the effects of a sudden shift away from the country, as world leaders threaten tougher sanctions.
content: Calls for companies to cut ties with Russia have taken on a new urgency, as world leaders push for even tougher sanctions in response to the horror of images of scores of dead civilians in parts of Ukraine recently occupied by Russian forces. The next steps could include a ban on Russian coal exports and further restrictions on Russia’s ability to access foreign currency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Luke Broadwater and Maggie Haberman
title: Justice Dept. Investigation of Jan. 6 Confronts Sprawling Cast of Characters
description: The wide net being cast by prosecutors as they move beyond charging rioters could encompass scores of potential witnesses from inside and outside of government.
content: Among the challenges facing the federal grand jury recently empaneled to investigate the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol is the sheer number of people who might have information relevant to its inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Stolen Darwin Notebooks, Missing for Decades, Are Returned
description: The two notebooks were anonymously returned to the Cambridge University Library 22 years after they went missing. A note addressed to the librarian read: “Happy Easter.”
content: Twenty-two years after a pair of notebooks filled with Charles Darwin’s early musings went missing from the Cambridge University Library, they were anonymously returned in good condition last month along with a note to the elated librarian: “Happy Easter.”
source.name: The New York Times

description: The visit to the White House by former President Barack Obama, one of the Democratic Party’s most popular figures, comes at a time when President Biden could use a boost.
content: WASHINGTON — Former President Barack Obama returned to the White House on Tuesday, the first visit he had made since departing in January 2017, to celebrate a new policy that expands coverage under the Affordable Care Act, his signature domestic policy achievement.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Primate Societies Are Surprisingly Complex. So Are Their Gender Roles.
description: Frans de Waal’s “Different” is a fascinating study of gender among monkeys and apes, but its account of human behavior is less satisfying.
content: This year marks the 40th anniversary of “Chimpanzee Politics,” a book that forced us to look at our simian cousins in a new light. The author, a Dutch primatologist named Frans de Waal, offered an unprecedented look at the social world of chimpanzees. Their lives are crammed with alliances, betrayals, and Machiavellian maneuvers. “Chimpanzee Politics” was also the debut of a gifted writer. De Waal turned what might have been a dry monograph into something that read more like a character-packed novel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg
title: Should Libraries Get Rid of Late Fees?
description: Public libraries in New York recently decided not to fine overdue books. Should all libraries do the same?
content: Have you ever held onto a library book past its due date? If so, did you pay a fine? Have fines made you more hesitant to use the library?

title: Trucking Companies Train You on the Job. Just Don’t Try to Quit.

content: Wayne Orr didn’t yet know that his foot was broken as he made his way back from Texas to his home in South Carolina, but he did know that he couldn’t continue pressing the pedals on the tractor-trailer he had been driving.

title: Woman Is Fatally Shot in Bronx Crossfire

title: Some Ukrainian Refugees Are Returning Home, Despite the Risks
description: A growing number of families, convinced the war could last for years, have decided that facing danger at home is better than life as a refugee.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — From her bearing and demeanor, the college instructor waiting at the Lviv bus station appeared to be accustomed to respect and, judging by her fur-trimmed coat and pink mohair hat adorned with a sparkling pin, used to a certain elegance.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Space Tourism Isn’t Just Joyriding
description: Having rich guys like Jeff Bezos in orbit can make space travel routine and help all of us dream big.

title: The Magic of Tiny-Home Videos
description: They’re an antidote to a widespread fantasy of living without constraints.
content: I wouldn’t mind living in a bathroom if it was the one at Jessica Alba’s family home, which has more windows (five) and shower heads (two) than my airless apartment in Queens. And Rainn Wilson’s pet pigs, who sleep in their own casita with a Dutch door — aptly called the Pig Palace — have already realized my pastoral fantasy and desire for more breathing space.

author: By Charlie Savage
title: More Evidence Bolsters Durham’s Case Against Democratic-Linked Lawyer
description: Separately, defense lawyers asked a judge to block the Trump-era special counsel from making the Steele dossier a focus of next month’s trial.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump-era special counsel scrutinizing the Russia investigation has acquired additional evidence that may bolster his case against a Democratic-linked lawyer accused of lying to the F.B.I. at a September 2016 meeting about Donald J. Trump’s possible ties to Russia, a new court filing revealed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu, Nadav Gavrielov and Jack Ewing
title: Here’s How Slowly New York City Is Moving on Electric Vehicles
description: New York has ambitious electrification goals, but it lags behind other major cities in the United States significantly.
content: There are just 15 electric public buses on the streets of New York, out of a fleet of more than 5,900 buses. There is just a single electric police patrol car, a Tesla, and only one electric garbage truck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: What are war crimes, and how are they prosecuted?
description: World leaders have vowed to hold President Vladimir V. Putin responsible for any atrocities by Russian forces. Past experience shows such cases take years to build and prosecute.
content: World leaders have vowed to hold President Vladimir V. Putin responsible for war crimes as evidence mounts that Russian forces killed civilians in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Noah Reid Preps for Parenthood With Plants and Nina Simone
description: The “Schitt’s Creek” star makes his Broadway debut this month in Tracy Letts’s new comedy “The Minutes.”
content: Noah Reid will be on the video call in a minute, his publicist tells me. The 34-year old “Schitt’s Creek” star, who played Dan Levy’s lover, Patrick Brewer, across four seasons of the Canadian comedy, just got home from a rehearsal for “The Minutes,” the new Tracy Letts comedy he’s starring in on Broadway. Then … Bam!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Lybarger
title: Love and Scandal, Buried for Years at an Elite Boarding School
description: In Jonathan Galassi’s “School Days,” a sexual harassment investigation uncovers long-buried memories of desire and abuse.
content: SCHOOL DAYSBy Jonathan Galassi
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: He Worked for Warhol, but That’s Just Part of the Story
description: Vito Giallo, 91, looks back at a life full of treasures.
content: By the time the body of the stone dealer was discovered in his Upper West Side apartment, it had been decomposing for several weeks. The summer of 1969 was a scorcher, and the smell was so repellent that city officials ordered the building’s superintendent, Stanley, to dispose of everything in the unit. Stanley thought he might make some money off the man’s antique furniture, so he called Wally Gibbs, an antiques dealer, who called his friend and peer Vito Giallo for an appraisal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica Ackerberg and Michael Gonchar
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘We Know the Pledge. Its Author, Maybe Not.’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about how a 13-year-old might have been the real author of the Pledge of Allegiance. Then they will decide: Should students regularly recite the pledge in school?
content: Featured Article: “We Know the Pledge. Its Author, Maybe Not.”  by Sam Roberts
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Louis C.K.’s Grammy, After ‘Global Amounts of Trouble,’ Draws Backlash
description: Some comedians are questioning how the Recording Academy saw fit to bestow an award to someone who had admitted to sexual misconduct.
content: “How was your last couple years?” the comedian Louis C.K. says to the audience on the first track to his album “Sincerely Louis CK.” “How was 2018 and 2019 for you guys? Anybody else get in global amounts of trouble?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington and Alan Blinder
title: Tiger Woods Says, ‘I Feel Like I Am Going to Play’ the Masters
description: Woods, who sustained significant leg injuries in a single-car crash in February 2021, has played several practice rounds at Augusta National this week.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — In a career defined by triumph, travail, resolve and resurrection, Tiger Woods on Tuesday vowed to attempt his most startling comeback yet: returning to golf’s greatest stage, the Masters Tournament, roughly 14 months after a car crash so devastating that doctors weighed amputating his right leg.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Lasdun
title: Sex Goddess, Celebrity and the Best Hope for Her Country
description: Miguel Syjuco’s novel “I Was the President’s Mistress!!” is a political satire told through interviews with a kaleidoscopic cast of characters.
content: I WAS THE PRESIDENT’S MISTRESS!!By Miguel Syjuco
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Shapiro
title: A Son Looks Back on Life With an Irascible and Beloved Mother
description: “Tasha” is Brian Morton’s memoir of his complicated relationship with the woman who raised him.
content: TASHAA Son’s MemoirBy Brian Morton
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Close
title: When an Advice Columnist Tries to Fix Her Daughters’ Issues
description: In her novel “The Wise Women,” Gina Sorell asks whether the fate of the shoemaker’s children also applies to the offspring of professional problem solvers.
content: THE WISE WOMENBy Gina Sorell
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adeel Hassan
title: The F.D.A. suspends use of a Glaxo antibody drug in the U.S. as an Omicron subvariant spreads.
description: Manufacturers said lab testing revealed that the authorized dosage of the drug was not sufficiently potent against BA.2.
content: Federal regulators said they were suspending use of a monoclonal antibody drug known as sotrovimab to treat high-risk Covid-19 patients in the United States because it was unlikely to be effective against the Omicron subvariant known as BA.2.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘Take Me Out,’ Whose Team Are You On?
description: Richard Greenberg’s 2002 play about baseball and homophobia gets a fine revival starring Jesse Williams and Jesse Tyler Ferguson.
content: Not for nothing is Darren Lemming, the fictional center fielder of a team called the Empires, also at the center of “Take Me Out,” Richard Greenberg’s gay fantasia on the national pastime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Fred Upton, House Republican Who Voted to Impeach Trump, Will Retire
description: Mr. Upton is the fourth House Republican who supported impeaching former President Donald Trump to decline to run for re-election.
content: Facing new district lines and a tough primary race, Representative Fred Upton of Michigan, announced his retirement on Tuesday, becoming the fourth House Republican who voted to impeach former President Donald J. Trump to decline to run for re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Pandemic Aid Bill Stalls Amid Dispute Over Immigration Restrictions
description: Republicans blocked a move to bring up a $10 billion Covid response package after Democrats refused to consider amendments, including one to keep in place pandemic-era immigration curbs.
content: WASHINGTON — An election-year dispute over immigration policy emerged on Tuesday as the latest obstacle to quick approval of a $10 billion coronavirus response bill, as Senate Republicans refused to advance the measure without a vote to keep in place pandemic-era border restrictions that President Biden has moved to lift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: With ‘Bittersweet,’ Can Susan Cain Replicate the Success of ‘Quiet’?
description: In her new book, the former lawyer and best-selling author turns her sights on a different word, one that certainly suits our times.
content: BITTERSWEETHow Sorrow and Longing Make Us WholeBy Susan Cain
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Responses to evidence of Russian atrocities in Ukraine.
content: Images of dead Ukrainians in the Kyiv suburb of Bucha, some with their hands tied and others haphazardly buried in pits, spurred shocked Western leaders yesterday to promise even tougher sanctions against Russia, including possibly on energy. The Kremlin dug in and showed signs of preparing a new assault. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Lessons Learned From Michele McNally
description: Two photographers share how Michele McNally, who shepherded a new age of photography at The New York Times, touched their lives and work.
content: Michele McNally, who served as The New York Times’s director of photography and then as a top newsroom manager, died on Feb. 18 at age 66. When she started at the newspaper in 2004, her mission was clear: to enhance The Times’s photojournalism and to show the newsroom just how powerful visual storytelling could be. She achieved both. Under her leadership, The Times won six Pulitzer Prizes for photography. But she also left a mark on the lives of those she worked with. Here, two Times photographers, Josh Haner and João Silva, share how Ms. McNally shaped The Times and their careers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Malin
title: Richard Linklater and Sandra Adair: Three Decades of Action and Cuts
description: The director and the editor have collaborated on 20 features, including “Apollo 10½,” now on Netflix.
content: In “Apollo 10½: A Space Age Childhood,” an animated comedy on Netflix set in the suburbs of 1960s Houston, a gaggle of preteens descend upon a Popsicle stand in a bid to ward off the Texas heat. One by one, they go for that first delightful lick, only to discover that their tongues instantly stick to the freezer-burned treats upon contact. Panic starts to spread, and the kids wriggle frantically, until — Rrrrip! — one daring boy ends up with a bloody tongue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Doug Mills
title: The Masters Ritual That’s in the Mail
description: Putting and chipping aside, a crucial step on the journey to winning a coveted green jacket is making sure to R.S.V.P.
content: AUGUSTA, Ga. — The invitations have come his way for half a century, and Ben Crenshaw, now 70 years old, has kept each and every one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William J. Broad
title: How America Watches for a Nuclear Strike
description: Hundreds of satellites and spacecraft are keeping an eye on Russia’s nuclear forces from above. So far, they haven’t seen much to worry about.
content: In late February, when President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia declared that his country’s nuclear arms were entering “special combat readiness,” America’s surveillance gear went on high alert. Hundreds of imaging satellites, as well as other private and federal spacecraft, began looking for signs of heightened activity among Russia’s bombers, missiles, submarines and storage bunkers, which hold thousands of nuclear warheads.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: Joe Manchin’s Brand Is Not Helping Democrats. But There’s a Republican Who Might.
description: It’s time to stop slathering so much attention on Joe Manchin.
content: They say the definition of insanity is doing the same thing over and over again and expecting a different result. This aphorism now leaps to mind every time I hear that the White House and congressional Democrats are trying yet again to win Senator Joe Manchin’s backing for this or that proposal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Jewish Man’s Death Near Paris Fuels Outrage on Election Eve
description: Newly surfaced video shows the man, who was hit by a tram in February, fleeing an assault. It has fueled suspicions of an antisemitic motive days before France’s presidential vote.
content: PARIS — When Jérémy Cohen, 31, a Jewish man living in a northern suburb of Paris, died in February after being hit by a tram, his death was initially reported as an accident and garnered little attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michal Leibowitz
title: ‘I Didn’t Feel Like Going, but I’m Glad I Did’: My Motto of the Moment
description: The pandemic turned many of us into hermits. It’s time to go out again.
content: One recent snowy Saturday morning, I coaxed myself out of bed, into semiformal attire and through the door to synagogue. It was the latest in a series of attempts to force myself to, well, do stuff, the kind of stuff that takes me out of my one-bedroom apartment and into human society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Woo
title: Twitter will stiffen moderation policies in response to the war in Ukraine.
description: Twitter will stop amplifying Russian government accounts and ban some tweets containing images of prisoners of war.
content: In response to censorship by Moscow and provocative posts about the war in Ukraine, Twitter detailed new policies on Tuesday that it said would reduce amplification of Russian government accounts and ban some tweets containing images of prisoners of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: The matchup between the big men will be one to watch.
description: Armando Bacot of North Carolina and David McCormack of Kansas have been two critical players for their teams, and will almost certainly have key roles in the championship game.
content: In a basketball world where elite guard play and sharpshooting is both cherished and prioritized, the outcome of this national championship game could be decided by the towering, physical players who make the most impact around the rim.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: In Houston, a Modernist Showplace With Some Brazilian Curves
description: After living abroad for years, one Brazilian couple wanted a home that showed off their roots. So they built it themselves.
content: Angelica and Gustavo Nechar moved many times in Brazil, where they were born and raised, and in France, where their careers flourished and they owned a Haussmann-style apartment in the 17th Arrondissement of Paris. But it wasn’t until Mr. Nechar’s work as a human-resources executive brought the couple to Houston in 2013 that they realized all of their previous homes had lacked one enticing thing: a design conceived just for them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Oklahoma Lawmakers Approve Near-Total Ban on Abortion
description: The measure is part of a wave of stringent abortion restrictions enacted by legislators in Republican-led states.
content: Lawmakers in Oklahoma on Tuesday approved a near-total ban on abortion, making it the latest Republican-led state to forge ahead with stringent abortion legislation as the Supreme Court weighs a case that could overturn Roe v. Wade later this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: He Quietly Turned Bank of America Around. Can He Do More?
description: Brian Moynihan’s cautious approach as C.E.O. fostered a turnaround after the 2008 financial crisis, but some question whether it’s holding the bank back now.
content: When Brian T. Moynihan arrived at Davos in the middle of a Swiss snowstorm in January 2010, just weeks after taking on the top job at Bank of America, he didn’t expect to be hit by a blizzard indoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Ivanka Trump Testifies to House Panel Investigating Jan. 6 Attack
description: The former president’s daughter and adviser was in the West Wing with him as a pro-Trump mob stormed the Capitol. She is said to have tried to persuade him to call off the rioters.
content: WASHINGTON — Ivanka Trump, former President Donald J. Trump’s eldest daughter, who served as one of his senior advisers, testified for about eight hours on Tuesday before the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, according to people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicolas Rapold
title: ‘RRR’ Review: A Hero (or Two) Shall Rise
description: Scenes of glorious excess make the screen hum with energy in S.S. Rajamouli’s action epic set in British colonial India.
content: It’s not long in “RRR” before a tiger and a wolf collide midair during a brawl with one of the film’s two musclebound heroes. Scenes of glorious excess make the screen hum with energy in the latest feature from S.S. Rajamouli, the director of the “Baahubali” blockbusters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pilar Guzmán
title: In Defense of Melancholy
description: Susan Cain’s new book examines how sadness makes us whole.
content: Have you ever wondered why we love sad songs, or get choked up at a “Thank you, Mom” Olympics commercial? Questions like these were the impetus for Susan Cain’s new book, “Bittersweet: How Sorrow and Longing Make Us Whole.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: Why Germany Can’t Just Pull the Plug on Russian Energy
description: Under increasing pressure to sever the country’s reliance on Russian energy, German officials must contend with deeply rooted economic ties.
content: Last year, Russia supplied more than half of the natural gas and about a third of all the oil that Germany burned to heat homes, power factories and fuel cars, buses and trucks. Roughly half of Germany’s coal imports, which are essential to its steel manufacturing, came from Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Caviar and canned tuna: Top Fed official points out income-based inflation gaps.
description: Lael Brainard, a governor of the Federal Reserve, highlighted the impact of inflation on the poor and pledged to act to cool off rising prices.
content: Caviar and canned tuna are grouped into the same category for the purposes of measuring the inflation rate in America, and Lael Brainard, a governor of the Federal Reserve, thinks that is obscuring the nation’s ability to understand the different price-related challenges facing households.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Can California Really Push Back Against Red States?
description: As conservative states move to enact far-right legislative agendas, California leaders say they’re spearheading the resistance.
content: If there’s one thing we know about California’s officials, it’s that they love to declare that California is a leader in everything — whether it’s tackling climate change or transforming the world through technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caleb Crain
title: Challenging Denial With Enduring Images
description: Jack Lowery’s “It Was Vulgar and It Was Beautiful” tells the story of the art collectives whose work became the iconography of a movement.
content: IT WAS VULGAR AND IT WAS BEAUTIFUL: How AIDS Activists Used Art to Fight a PandemicBy Jack Lowery
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ingrid K. Williams
title: Can A.I.-Driven Voice Analysis Help Identify Mental Disorders?
description: Early tests have been promising, but issues involving bias, privacy and mistrust of “black box” algorithms are possible pitfalls.
content: This article is part of a limited series on artificial intelligence’s potential to solve everyday problems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Hammer
title: In ‘The King’s Shadow,’ a Long Forgotten Spy Returns to the Spotlight
description: Edmund Richardson’s latest book revisits the tale of Charles Masson, a runaway British soldier who reinvented himself as an archaeologist and a spy.
content: THE KING’S SHADOWObsession, Betrayal, and the Deadly Quest for the Lost City of AlexandriaBy Edmund Richardson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Garbageman’ Review: Just a Couple of Straw Men
description: In Keith Huff’s new play, two friends head to the Jan. 6 insurrection, but this production substitutes unfunny cartoonishness for the characters’ humanity.
content: The title of Keith Huff’s new play, “Garbageman,” shouldn’t be taken at face value, even though Huff pretty much asks you to.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon LaFraniere
title: The C.D.C. director says she ‘really would encourage’ second boosters for older people and many with chronic conditions.
description: The remarks by the director, Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky — on shots to Americans 50 to 64 with underlying medical conditions and all those 65 and older — were her clearest statement to date.
content: Dr. Rochelle P. Walensky, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, said Tuesday that her agency “really would encourage people who are over 50 who have underlying medical conditions and those over the age of 65” to get a second booster shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger, Mike Isaac and Lauren Hirsch
title: Elon Musk Joins Twitter’s Board, Pitching Ideas Big and Small
description: Free speech, open-source algorithms — and an edit button: The world’s richest person will soon help steer the social media platform where he has a huge following.
content: Elon Musk, the world’s richest man, reached out to Parag Agrawal, Twitter’s chief executive, a few weeks ago with a friendly heads-up. He was buying shares of the social media company, Mr. Musk confided, and wanted to discuss how to make Twitter better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Arthur Lubow
title: A Lover’s Impact on David Wojnarowicz, for All to See
description: A show at PPOW gallery explores the artist and author’s first significant relationship, with Jean Pierre Delage, which liberated him emotionally and changed him artistically.
content: During an eight-month visit to Paris when he was 24, David Wojnarowicz embarked on his first serious love affair and began to take himself seriously as a visual artist. The full import of these changes became evident after his return to New York in June 1979, once he uncorked a stream of fervent letters to his lover, Jean Pierre Delage, and included drawings, photographs and other art work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: The Unsinkable Molly Shannon
description: In a new memoir, “Hello, Molly!”, Shannon — the “Saturday Night Live” alumna — recounts her comedy career and the devastating family tragedy that changed her life.
content: LOS ANGELES — Just as I arrived for our lunchtime appointment, Molly Shannon came gliding up Larchmont Boulevard on a Trek bicycle, looking for ways to spread her personal brand of eccentric joy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Tony Hawk: Until the Wheels Fall Off’ Review: Shred Until Shredded
description: This new documentary about the pro skateboarder Tony Hawk explores his compulsion to continue skating at all costs.
content: The professional skateboarder Tony Hawk is revered for his indefatigability and inventiveness: He’s originated over 100 skateboard tricks, according to “Tony Hawk: Until the Wheels Fall Off,” a new documentary about his bumpy rise to fame. In interview footage in this movie, directed by Sam Jones, Hawk also seems an amiable enough fellow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Zelensky Addresses the U.N.
description: The Ukrainian leader described war crimes he said Russian troops had committed.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: A Viral Case Against Crypto, Explored
description: The video essayist Dan Olson explains the dangers lurking in the culture and ideology that surround digital currency.
content: The hype around cryptocurrencies has reached a fever pitch. There are Super Bowl ads for crypto companies featuring celebrities like Matt Damon and Larry David. The Staples Center in Los Angeles is now the Crypto.com Arena. And behind that hype is a distinct vision: a more decentralized economy where individuals have more autonomy over their finances, a grass-roots internet free of the not-so-invisible hand of Big Tech, and a cultural ecosystem where artists and musicians can fairly monetize their work. Back in October, I had the crypto investor Katie Haun on the show to make that case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: ‘I-65 Killer’ Who Terrorized Motel Clerks in the 1980s Is Identified
description: The authorities said they connected Harry Edward Greenwell, who died in 2013, to at least three murders in Kentucky and Indiana, using genetic genealogy.
content: His chosen conduit for terror was Interstate 65, preying on women working as night clerks at motels along the highway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor, Johnny Diaz and Christine Chung
title: Severe Weather in the South: Here’s What to Know
description: Five tornadoes touched down in Mississippi, a man was killed in his Texas home by a falling tree and more wild weather is in store for the Southeast.
content: Five tornadoes touched down in Mississippi and at least one tornado struck in South Carolina on Tuesday as meteorologists and emergency officials braced for another round of unsettling storms in parts of the South on Wednesday, following a recent pattern of unpredictable weather in the region.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Pérez-Peña
title: Zelensky Accuses Russia of Atrocities and Criticizes U.N.’s Inaction
description: In a blistering address to the United Nations Security Council, Ukraine’s president asked what use the body was if it would not intervene to stop a war of aggression.
content: With evidence mounting of atrocities in the Kyiv suburbs, and Russian forces preparing for a new offensive farther east, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine delivered a scathing speech to the United Nations on Tuesday, accusing Russia of a litany of horrors and questioning whether a world body that takes no action to stop a war serves any purpose.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Jason Kilar, Head of WarnerMedia, Is Leaving Ahead of Discovery Merger
description: Mr. Kilar helped HBO Max exceed expectations, but upset some top Hollywood filmmakers in the process.
content: Jason Kilar, the head of WarnerMedia, who came aboard with ambitious plans for the company’s stand-alone streaming service and wound up serving half his tenure effectively as a lame duck, announced on Tuesday that he was leaving the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Mob Hit Man Who Escaped as Sentence Neared Its End Is Recaptured
description: The apprehension of Dominic Taddeo, a notorious hit man from New York, came a week after he failed to return from a medical appointment to his halfway house in Florida.
content: Looks like Dominic Taddeo’s big breakout was more like a spring break.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Rob Szypko, Rachel Quester, Michael Johnson, Liz O. Baylen, Chelsea Daniel, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: How the War in Ukraine is Creating a Global Food Crisis
description: Russia’s invasion has severely disrupted how the world feeds itself.
content: Ukraine and Russia are enormous producers of wheat, corn, barley, sunflower oil and fertilizer. One study calculated that the two countries accounted for 12 percent of the world’s calories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Gladstone
title: Zelensky vilifies Russia over atrocities: ‘They killed entire families.’
description: The Ukrainian president delivered one of his most forceful denunciations of the invasion in a live video speech to the United Nations Security Council on Tuesday.
content: Raging at Russia over growing evidence of atrocities, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Tuesday delivered one of his most forceful denunciations of the invasion in a live video speech to the United Nations Security Council, calling the Russians war criminals who he said had killed families, raped women in front of their children, pillaged homes and left his country in ruins, “filled with mass graves.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Conger
title: Hackers’ Fake Claims of Ukrainian Surrender Aren’t Fooling Anyone. So What’s Their Goal?
description: Experts say the hackers’ intentions might not be to actually trick anyone, but to erode confidence in Ukrainian media outlets and institutions.
content: WASHINGTON — Andriy Taranov, a board member at the Ukrainian public broadcasting company Suspilne, was sitting in his office last month when he noticed a strange message running across the bottom of the television screen. It said Volodymyr Zelensky, the president of Ukraine, had announced a surrender.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: With Discovery merger pending, Warner Bros. chief Ann Sarnoff is set to leave.
description: Ms. Sarnoff became the first woman to hold the job in 2019, but Discovery’s C.E.O. is expected to take over at least some of her role himself.
content: LOS ANGELES — Ann Sarnoff, the chief executive of the WarnerMedia Studios and Networks Group, will leave the company, with an announcement coming as soon as this week, three people briefed on the matter said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Writers Gather to Discuss the Role of Literature in Times of War and Isolation
description: The PEN World Voices Festival will bring together hundreds of writers, among them Abdulrazak Gurnah, Alejandro Zambra and Gary Shteyngart, and will include an address by Andrey Kurkov, a Ukrainian novelist.
content: In 1939, the American journalist Dorothy Thompson, who was expelled from Germany after reporting on the rise of the Nazi movement, convened an emergency summit of writers in response to the violence unfolding in Europe. As the leader of PEN America, a literary and free speech organization, Thompson called on writers to unite against fascism and threats to free expression. The event drew 500 writers from 30 countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Stacy Cowley
title: Student Loans Are Set to Be Paused Again, Pushing Payments to September
description: The White House is said to be planning to announce the sixth extension of the pandemic relief program, affecting tens of millions of borrowers.
content: President Biden will allow millions of federal student loan borrowers to freeze their payments until Aug. 31, according to an administration official briefed on the matter, the latest extension of a pandemic relief measure that began more than two years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Boyle
title: Ronald Reagan’s New Economic Order, and What It Meant for America
description: Gary Gerstle’s “The Rise and Fall of the Neoliberal Order” traces the political shifts that have characterized modern American history.
content: THE RISE AND FALL OF THE NEOLIBERAL ORDERAmerica and the World in the Free Market EraBy Gary Gerstle
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Friskics-Warren
title: Roland White, a Shaper of Bluegrass and Country-Rock, Dies at 83
description: A mandolin player and singer, he made his mark with the Country Boys (later renamed the Kentucky Colonels), and his influence extended into the rock of the ’60s.
content: NASHVILLE — Roland White, a mandolin player and singer who helped shape major developments in bluegrass and country-rock over a seven-decade career, died here on Friday. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juli Min
title: Shanghai Avoided Covid Disaster for Two Years. Now We’re Locked Down.
description: What it’s like to lock down after two years free of Covid worries.
content: SHANGHAI — The volunteers in full protective gear — called big whites here in China — have packed up and moved on for the day; the apartment complex where I live is once again sequestered in silence. From my 18th-floor window, I can see the koi ponds and gardens below, empty; the hedge maze, empty; the fountain, somehow turned off, its waters unmoving as though in allegiance, in reprieve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Lambs Club Reopens With Michael White as Executive Chef
description: A pop-up behind Oxalis puts down roots in Clinton Hill; a piano bar lands in the Upper East Side; and more restaurant news.
content: The Stanford White-designed building that, since 2010, has been the Chatwal Hotel was originally built as a home for the Lambs Club, a theater group, for which the hotel’s bar and restaurant is now named. A bright spot for theater district dining for more than a decade, it has been closed since the start of the pandemic, but will reopen early next week with Michael White, in his return to New York, as executive chef. (He replaces Geoffrey Zakarian, who departed in the fall.) Mr. White was a partner in the Altamarea Group (Marea, Osteria Morini, Ai Fiori, etc.), but severed his ties with the group and left New York almost two years ago, and wound up in Surfside, Fla., where he became the executive chef of the Lido Restaurant at The Surf Club, a post he will retain. “It’s been like a sabbatical,” he said. His food will maintain Mr. Zakarian’s high-end American style; Mr. White is planning a seasonal array, with Montauk fluke crudo, asparagus hollandaise with morels, steak tartare, roast chicken with artichokes and snap peas, a strip steak with peppercorn sauce, and what he’s calling the Stanford White burger with raclette cheese. “It’s a great opportunity for me not to do something that’s strictly Italian, to step outside my box,” he said. But he’ll also slip in Italian tastes with lobster spaghettini and a risotto. The restaurant’s deep wine cellar remains available. A handsome restaurant with a fireplace, Art Deco touches, red leather upholstery and an upstairs bar, all designed by Thierry Despont, Lambs Club has undergone some cosmetic fixes without altering its elegance. Grand Tour Hospitality is running the restaurant in partnership with David Rabin, a partner since its inception, and Mr. White. (Opens Monday)

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Quietly, Foolishly Eloped’

content: I have a drawer full of magic. Serums, powders, creams, all promising to reverse time. Every day it takes me a bit longer to look how I think I should. My daughter, now 14, says she has no interest in “patriarchal standards of beauty.” I am at once glad and worried: glad she won’t be joining me on this Sisyphean road but worried she may be judged for her choice. I am also optimistic; perhaps someday I can walk away from my regimen. Until then, I am proud of my daughter for her confidence in opting out of my wishful thinking. — Jenny Fan Raj

title: America’s Vanishing Kingdom
description: My father fled Vietnam only to spend the rest of his life in American factories helping shore up the same military that had set our family adrift.
content: My dad’s American dream was made of aluminum. Not that he would have put it that way. He did not talk much, and never about his dreams, but most days for nearly 25 years he headed off to a factory and turned aluminum and other metals into parts and a paycheck. He started at the Torrington Company, once one of the largest producers of metal bearings in North America and the biggest employer in Torrington, Conn., where we somehow found ourselves in 1980. Half a decade had passed since the fall of Saigon. My dad had been in and out of a re-education camp; we had been in and out of refugee camps. After we did stints in Thailand and Hong Kong, someone, somewhere sent us to Torrington. My father died there three decades later, having spent the rest of his life making industrial and military supplies in America’s gun belt.

content: The story is so good it hurts to hear. In an era of stupefying inequality, one of the most famous members of the upper class is a former drug dealer from a notorious public-housing project. He switched the product and rode CD sales to a new ZIP code. He went from nobody to somebody to a fixture in public consciousness who hangs out with a former president. content: “You have to be patient because you can’t control thunderstorms,” says Frank Bry, 59, a sound effects recordist who creates libraries of sounds that he sells to video-game, television, movie and white-noise production companies. Bry has four collections of thunderstorm recordings collected over 30 years from his home in rural northern Idaho. Know that the landscape around you will shape how thunder sounds. Bry lives near a large lake surrounded by mountain ranges, resulting in a volume and resonance he calls “bodacious.” Still, he covets the way thunder peals over the deserts of New Mexico. “I’ve heard pretty phenomenal thunder recordings from there,” Bry says. “The sound is crisp and dry.”

title: College Became the Default. Let’s Rethink That.
description: Imagine a world that gave high schoolers more options.
content: I graduated from Rutgers University in 1985 and recently had occasion to visit the campus. I was struck, just as I was decades ago, by the contrast between the look of the dormitories built early in the 20th century like Ford Hall (1915) and Hegeman Hall (1922) and that of the great many put up after World War II such as Frelinghuysen Hall (1956) and Mettler Hall (1964). University campuses tend to harbor that kind of contrast between the doughty old ones and the mid-century-modern-ish new ones. Often, the proliferation of the latter allowed the schools to accommodate a vast increase in the student body in the wake of the G.I. Bill after the war.
